text:
A drama about an attack on a mosque is headlining the third Saudi Film Festival, which opens on Thursday amid hopes the conservative kingdom may finally allow public cinemas.

The modest festival, which will feature 70 productions in competition, is a far cry from the glitz and glamour of Western counterparts. The austere version of Islam practised in Saudi Arabia bans cinemas and other entertainment venues. But organisers hope the event, which will see screenings take place at an arts and cultural centre in the Gulf coast city of Dammam, will help develop the country’s nascent film industry.

“We try to raise the standards, to make it better,” festival director Ahmed AlMulla said. The festival will culminate on Monday night with winners of the juried competition receiving its Golden Palm Tree awards.

Rakan AlHarbi’s four-minute drama Their Stained Hearts will be one of three short films shown to hundreds of guests expected at the red-carpet opening gala.

The film tells the story of a “museum for terrorists” — where a visitor talks to the attacker of a mosque. — AFP
title: Mosque attack drama opens Saudi film festival
